title: Sheryl Crow on Recording Her Final Album
text:
On the eve of the release of what she has said is her final album, Sheryl Crow is on the back porch of her home in Nashville, in her house slippers with a cup of coffee. It’s a late August morning, milder than usual for Nashville, and Crow is just back from a girls’ trip to Blackberry Mountain, a resort in the Great Smoky Mountains in Walland, Tennessee. Though confident in her decision, she says that Threads, which came out August 30 from The Valory Music Co., will be her final “full artistic statement.” The record is a culmination of sorts of the songwriter’s decades-long career, a testament to the friendships and connections she’s made in her career.

Threads started while Crow, 57, was recording with Kris Kristofferson. She and Kristofferson recorded a new version of his 1972 song “Border Lord,” and from there, Crow decided she’d call up some friends to collaborate. Crow brought together old legends and legends in the making: Neil Young and country artists Lukas Nelson and Margo Price join Crow on “Cross Creek Road,” which she wrote with her longtime songwriting partner Jeff Trott; Public Enemy’s Chuck D, blues guitarist Gary Clark Jr. and soul singer Andra Day come together for the anti–gun violence track “Story of Everything”; Stevie Nicks and Maren Morris harmonize on opener “Prove You Wrong”; and Bonnie Raitt and Mavis Staples jam with Crow on the bluesy “Live Wire.” Eric Clapton, Sting, Willie Nelson, Emmylou Harris and James Taylor all make appearances as well.

Crow, who at one point does her dishes while on the phone (“Always multitasking,” she says, “always multitasking”), gets choked up while talking about the threads in her musical and personal life that led to this record—particularly when mentioning her children, 12-year-old Wyatt and 9-year-old Levi. Though Threads might sound more like a classic rock or country album than her 1993 debut, Tuesday Night Music Club, Crow’s new record stays true to her style. Here, she tells WSJ. how it all came about and what she hopes for the future.

Will Threads really be your last album? How did you come to that decision?

Well, I say, Never say never. [But] I’m very comfortable with this being my last full artistic statement. I think it’s a wonderful way to end that tradition of making albums. I’ll definitely continue to write music, and as it seems pertinent, I’ll put songs out. We had such a great experience last year with the song “Wouldn’t Want to Be Like You” and the fact that it was so immediate, addressing what was happening in the world—particularly in the United States, particularly in our government—with the idea that the truth has become so inconvenient. To be able to just put something out and have it feel of-the-moment, there’s something wonderful about that. The other thing is that with technology, people are making their own playlists, cherry-picking songs, and I’m not convinced they listen to albums anymore. Maybe the tried-and-true fan does, but for the most part your music winds up on playlists.

So you’re not just fed up with the album recording process after so many decades? Your decision is more of a reaction to the music landscape right now?

It’s more about not being able to put the toothpaste back in the tube. We are where we are, technology-wise, and people get music the way they get it. If I were to make a decision about recording more albums based on my experience with this one, I would make albums every day of my life. It was such a wonderful experience. So emotional and humbling to be able to work with all these artists. That’s another reason that I love this being sort of my swan song, because it’s really the summation of my musical career, my musical life. Starting with reading album covers as a 7- or 8-year-old girl in a tiny town of three stoplights, to many, many years later, reflecting on how many heroes I’ve met and how much they’ve enhanced my life.

Given all your collaborating, especially on this record, how do you remain Sheryl Crow?

To be honest, and I say this unabashedly, I have made a career out of “tributing” my influences. I wear them on my sleeve. I’m proud of the people I listened to growing up, and they are part of my musical fiber. It wasn’t hard for me to sit down and think about what kind of song would hold the weight for Willie Nelson to want to sing it. I just dipped into that mind-set.

I’m proud of my influences! And I feel like the younger people on this record, you can hear where they’ve come from.

Does any one story from the recording process stick out to you?

I have a gazillion stories. Or as my 9-year-old would say: “eleventy-million.” One of my favorites—and this is one that, to me, is the perfect illustration of this album: I was a young schoolteacher in St. Louis in the mid-’80s, and I went to see the Chuck Berry [documentary] Hail! Hail! Rock ‘n’ Roll being filmed. I was in the audience, and there was Keith Richards, and there was Steve Jordan, who produced [Threads]. Cut to some 30-odd years later, here I am with this record, and having spent two days in New York City with my dear friend Keith and the captain of my ship, Steve Jordan. You can’t write that in a movie and have it be believable. In some ways, this album is the journey between my being in that audience as a young schoolteacher, to now. And the incredible road trip that has occurred.

Did you see that Maren Morris said [her Country supergroup] The Highwomen wouldn’t exist without you?

Listen, that makes me cry. Because they are just amazing. They are tremendous, and they are the real deal, and I love every one of them. [Highwomen member] Brandi [Carlile] is on this record, and she will make you cry singing “Beware of Darkness,” the George Harrison song. Being the mother she is, the mother earth she is. I mean, wow. I love that.

Why did you choose that song of his to cover?

If he were alive, he would have been my first call. The way he lived his life was such an inspiration to my own meditation practice, and the idea of manifesting peace within in order to manifest peace without. I knew him a little bit, through the years, before he passed. That song felt so necessary to me for this record because of my children, the idea that we’re at a point in our evolution where we really have to warn against darkness. We have to teach our young children that what resonates as darkness, that’s probably [darkness]. Right now, that’s a heavy message.

What’s being a mom like for you?

It’s the best thing that’s ever happened to my life, and I barely remember my life before my kids. It’s been incredible showing them the world. It’s been humbling, as of late, to know that what I model to them informs so deeply who they will become and how they will see the world. The unfortunate thing about it is, they’re very young and should be totally experiencing life filled with innocence. They’re asking the hard questions that I don’t have answers for. That part of it makes me mad, and it winds up on the records. I can’t shake that when I walk in to write a song. The fact that my 9-year-old is worrying about not being able to breathe—in his lifetime! I mean that’s crazy, that they’re already experiencing the idea of mortality, and they’re not even teenagers yet. It’s an amazing thing to be their mom, and kids are much more aware and probably more savvy than I was when I was 10. But it’s full-time. It definitely makes you straighten your back up and really think about the decisions you make and the words you speak.

Is there a song from Threads they especially like?

They love “Prove You Wrong.” I think because of the beat, and they’ve heard it a lot. My 12-year-old learned how to play “Live Wire,” and he was all about that for a while, probably because of the groove. He was playing cello in the orchestra in school, and he came home one day and said, “I’m switching to bass.” And I said, “Why are you switching to bass? You were so great on cello!” And he said, “Because you play bass, and I want to be in your band when I turn 19.” So, once I quit crying about it, I had this flash of, “When you’re 19, the last person you’re going to want to play with in their band is your mom, but I love you.” That right there is manna from heaven. Just kill me now!

This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.
description: The Americana songwriter on her star-studded album Threads and what it’s like to make music with her heroes
